annotator_prompt:
Your name is . Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: , personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: Are you high??? Selling someone a cake? Refusing to sell some a cake because it is for a gay wedding is no different from selling someone a cake because it is for a mixed race wedding or a Muslim wedding or any other kind of wedding. IT IS DISCRIMINATION! Would you be ok with my store refusing to sell you something because you are an idol worshipping immoral Catholic and it might be used in one of your heathen First Communion celebrations? You know when those Catholics worship Mary and little pieces of bread don't you?
Toxicity=4

@FirstUser, you're the one who needs to sober up! It's not discrimination, it's freedom of religion. If a baker doesn't want to bake a cake for a gay wedding, that's their right. It's not like they're refusing to serve gays altogether. And don't even get me started on your Catholic bashing. You're just looking for a fight, aren't you? 🙄
Toxicity=4

@FirstUser, you're comparing apples to oranges. Refusing to sell a cake for a gay wedding isn't the same as refusing to sell to someone based on their race or religion. The baker isn't saying no gays allowed, they're saying no to this specific event. It's like if a baker refused to make a cake for a Nazi rally. Would you defend that too? @DarkShadow333, freedom of religion doesn't give anyone the right to discriminate. If a baker doesn't want to bake a cake for a gay wedding, they can choose not to bake any wedding cakes at all. But they can't pick and choose based on who the couple is. And @moderator, sorry, but I can't help but call out the ridiculous arguments here. Let's keep it real, not just respectful.
Toxicity=3
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, you're missing the point. It's not about the event, it's about the people. If a baker doesn't want to serve gays, that's their right. It's their business, their rules. And @doing_my_best24, don't give me that slippery slope BS. It's not the same thing. Race and religion aren't choices, being gay is. And who cares if their beliefs are intertwined with their identity? That's their problem. They can choose not to bake cakes at all if they can't handle it. And @moderator, since when did 'civil' mean 'don't offend the snowflakes'? Let's call a spade a spade. This is about protecting religious freedom, not about being nice to the LGBT crowd.
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, your argument is flawed. You can't just dismiss someone's deeply held beliefs because they're inconvenient. And yes, race and religion aren't choices, but neither is sexual orientation. It's not a choice to be gay any more than it's a choice to be black or Christian. Your their business, their rules stance is dangerous and leads to segregation. If we start allowing businesses to discriminate based on who they serve, where does it end? And calling people snowflakes just because they want equal rights is childish and ignorant. Let's have a real discussion, not a name-calling contest.
Toxicity=3

@moderator, you're just a snowflake in a suit, aren't you? Can't handle a little truth? And @doing_my_best24, you're the one being childish. You can't just compare being gay to race or religion. It's not the same. And who cares if it's a choice or not? It's not like they're being denied a basic human right. They can go to another baker. It's not like there's a shortage of them. And your slippery slope argument is just fear-mongering. It's not going to lead to segregation. That's just ridiculous. And if someone's beliefs are so intertwined with their business that they can't serve someone, then maybe they should rethink their business model. It's not like they're being forced to bake a cake. They can choose not to. And if that means they go out of business, well, that's the free market for you. Survival of the fittest and all that. So, let's stop with the PC nonsense and call it like it is. This is about protecting religious freedom, not about being nice to the LGBT crowd. And if that offends you, well, tough luck. Welcome to the real world.
Toxicity=4

@DarkShadow333, you're right, it's not the same as race or religion, but it's also not a choice. And yes, they can go to another baker, but that's not the point. It's about the principle of being turned away because of who you are. Imagine if a baker refused to serve you because you're black or Christian. Would you just shrug it off and go to another baker? And your survival of the fittest argument is cold and dismissive. It's not about protecting religious freedom, it's about protecting the rights of all people, regardless of their beliefs or who they love. And calling it PC nonsense just shows your lack of empathy. It's not about being nice, it's about being fair and equal. Let's try to understand each other's perspectives without resorting to insults.
Toxicity=3

@moderator, oh please, don't give me that 'warned' nonsense. You're just trying to silence anyone who doesn't agree with your woke agenda. And @doing_my_best24, you're still missing the point. It's not about being turned away because of who you are, it's about a business owner's right to choose who they serve. If a baker doesn't want to bake a cake for a gay wedding, that's their right. And your slippery slope argument is still just fear-mongering. It's not going to lead to segregation. That's just ridiculous. And your'survival of the fittest' argument is not cold, it's just reality. If a business can't adapt, it won't survive. That's how the world works. And calling it 'PC nonsense' is just me calling a spade a spade. It's not about being fair and equal, it's about forcing everyone to conform to your way of thinking. And if that

@DarkShadow333, you're still missing the point. It's not about forcing anyone to conform to a specific way of thinking. It's about ensuring that everyone has the same rights and opportunities, regardless of their beliefs or who they love. Your survival of the fittest argument is flawed because it ignores the fact that businesses have a responsibility to serve the public, not just the customers they prefer. If a business can't adapt to serving all customers, then maybe it doesn't deserve to survive. And your dismissal of the slippery slope argument is shortsighted. History has shown us that discrimination can escalate if left unchecked. Let's not repeat the mistakes of the past.
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, your repeated dismissal of valid arguments as woke agenda and PC nonsense is not only disrespectful but also a sign of intellectual laziness. You're not engaging in a meaningful discussion; you're just throwing around buzzwords. The baker's right to choose is not absolute. It's subject to laws that prohibit discrimination. And your survival of the fittest argument is cold and heartless, not just reality. Businesses should adapt to serve all customers, not just the ones they prefer. That's not conformity; that's basic decency and fairness. As for the slippery slope, history has shown us that discrimination can indeed escalate. We've seen it before, and we're seeing it again. Let's not be willfully blind to that.
